      46                 :            : 
      47                 :            : // Returns true if the std::string implementation supports a resize where
      48                 :            : // the new characters added to the std::string are left untouched.
      49                 :            : //
      50                 :            : // (A better name might be "STLStringSupportsUninitializedResize", alluding to
      51                 :            : // the previous function.)
      52                 :            : template <typename string_type>
      53                 :            : inline constexpr bool STLStringSupportsNontrashingResize(string_type*) {
      54                 :            :   return HasResizeUninitialized<string_type>();
      55                 :            : }
      56                 :            : 
      57                 :            : // Like str->resize(new_size), except any new characters added to "*str" as a
      58                 :            : // result of resizing may be left uninitialized, rather than being filled with
      59                 :            : // '0' bytes. Typically used when code is then going to overwrite the backing
      60                 :            : // store of the std::string with known data. Uses a Google extension to std::string.
